title: How a drug dealer ran a cannabis empire from prison with the help of a hospital porter
text:
How a drug dealer ran a cannabis empire from prison with the help of a hospital porter Three men have been jailed after two drugs farms were discovered Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A drug dealer ran a ‘cannabis empire’ from behind bars - with the help of a hospital porter. 
Thomas Rayment, 26, of Green Hill, Prestwich, was remanded at HMP Forest Bank, back in May 2015, after his network of cannabis farms was raided by police. 
The operations - at addresses in Bury, Wythenshawe and Cheetham Hill - were capable of yielding thousands of pounds worth of the drug. 
Within a few weeks of his incarceration, Rayment got his cousin, 24-year-old hospital porter Daniel Williams, to smuggle him a sim card into prison. 
Armed with the SIM, Rayment was able to ring his mum and girlfriend on a contraband phone and to carry on running his drug enterprise, with Daniel Williams help, while serving time on remand. 
From his jail cell, Rayment conspired with Williams to set up two new farms with a £14,000 yield. Williams set up one at at his own home at Vesper Street, Failsworth, and another at the Moston home of his 53-year-old father, Glenn Williams. Read More Urgent recall of Co-op's chocolate Easter bunny as police probe 'battery' tampering fears 
By the time the new farms were discovered in October 2015, Rayment had pleaded guilty to the earlier offences and was just five days into a 27-month sentence. 
But the discovery of the new farms means that Rayment has now been jailed for another three years after admitting production of cannabis, causing another person to bring a SIM card into prison and possession of mobile phones in prison. 
Daniel Williams, who was working as a porter at the Royal Oldham Hospital at the time, was sentenced to one year and 11 months in prison after he pleaded guilty to conspiracy to produce cannabis and bringing a SIM card into prison. 
Glenn Williams, of Margaret Ashton Close, admitted allowing premises to be used to cultivate cannabis and was given a 12-month community order. 
Defending, Rob Kearney said Rayment had been a ‘significant user’ of cannabis himself, but after doing courses in jail ‘realised the control cannabis had upon him’. Read More Police find half a million pounds worth of drugs among frozen pizzas and chips in Oldham home 
“He had to see his father’s funeral in handcuffs”, Mr Kearney added. 
Richard Vardon, defending Daniel Williams, said he suffered from ‘severe depression’ and had lost the hospital porter’s job he had been ‘proud of’. 
“It began as a grow for his own personal use - but soon morphed into some very different”, Mr Vardon added. Thomas Rayment (L) and Daniel Williams 
Rachel Faux, defending Glenn Williams, said there was little prospect of him being back before the courts. She said: “He’s vulnerable because of his poor health - he has a history of strokes - and vulnerable because he’s the father of a child who asked him to help out.” 
Sentencing, Judge Martin Steiger QC said: “Rayment had significant degree of control over his cannabis empire once he had been sent to prison.” Read More Teacher jailed after hurling drunken racist abuse - and MOCKING a brain-damaged passenger on a plane 
Detective Sergeant Andy Buckthorpe, of GMP’s Challenger Manchester, said: “The seizure of these plants ensured a significant amount of cannabis was unable find its way on to the streets of Greater Manchester and fund further criminal activity. 
“Today’s sentence should send a firm message to anyone who thinks they can get away with cultivating and supplying illegal drugs.” Like us on Facebook
